keyTakeAways: Indigenous knowledge, including traditional warning signals like gunfire, fire, and natural signs, plays a critical role in early flood detection in mountainous regions of Pakistan.

Despite significant investment in early warning systems (EWS), communities in Gilgit-Baltistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa lack trust due to equipment failures, poor maintenance, and lack of community involvement.
Residents have relied on human-based early warning systems, such as those passed down through generations, to save lives during glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs).
A lack of operational EWS and institutional trust has led to real-life incidents where villagers, not automated systems, are the ones who detect and alert others to danger.
The Pakistani government has invested over $37 million in EWS since 2017, yet no real-time link exists between local human sensors and official rescue teams.
The World Bank notes that Pakistan has warmed at twice the global average rate, increasing climate vulnerability, especially in high-altitude regions with glaciers.
Pakistan is among the top 10 most climate-vulnerable nations despite contributing less than 1% of global emissions.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Wasiyat Khan exemplifies how Indigenous knowledge and personal action can save lives in the absence of functioning EWS systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In northern Pakistan’s mountainous regions, particularly Gilgit-Baltistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Indigenous knowledge systems—such as recognizing unusual animal behavior, heavy rain, or using traditional signals like gunfire or fire—are proving more effective than government early warning systems in detecting and responding to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs). Despite spending over $37 million on EWS projects like GLOF-II, communities report widespread distrust due to frequent system failures, lack of real-time communication, and poor community engagement. Real-life examples, such as shepherds Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain, show how traditional knowledge and community-driven action have saved lives, while official systems remain ineffective or unresponsive. This highlights a broader challenge: climate resilience cannot rely solely on technology without community trust, cultural sensitivity, and participatory design.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
